page.title: 03The Dissolution
page.content: {Henry III}by his frequent pilgramages and royal patronage caused the fame of the{Holy House}to spread and wayside chapels giving comfort to pilgrims were built in all corners of the land.In{1534}the priory acknowledged{ {Henry VIII}to be the supreme head of the church and in{1538}the King took possession of the priory and demolished it,burning the statue of Our Lady of Walsingham at Chelsea.Little remains of the Priory apart from the{West Gate},the great{ {East Window},the{Refectory}and the original{Holy Wells}.These are in the grounds of a large house owned by{John {Gurney}and known as{The Abbey}.A raised area of lawn is the site of the Holy House.Excavations have uncovered the foundations of the encasing chapel.
